original_title: Historical Microsoft and Apple Artifacts Among First Christie’s Auction of Living Computers Museum
original_content:
Recently the Christies auction house released the list of items that would be going up for sale as part of the first lot of Living Computer Museum items, under the banner “Gen One: Innovations from the Paul G. Allen Collection”. One auction covers many firsts in the history of computing,  including a range of computers like an Apple 1, and a PDP-10, as well as early Microsoft memos and code printouts. The other auctions include such items like a Gemini Spacesuit as worn by [Ed White] and a signed 1939 letter from [Albert Einstein] to [US President Roosevelt] on the discovery by the Germans of a fissionable form of uranium from which a nuclear weapon could be constructed.
We previously reported on this auction when it was first announced in June of this year. At the time many were saddened at seeing the only computer history and its related educational facilities vanish, and there were worries among those who had donated items to the museum what would happen to these now that the museums inventory was being put up for sale. As these donations tend to be unconditional, the museum is free to do with the item as they see fit, but being sold at auction to probably a private collector was likely not on their mind when filling in the donation form.
As the first auctions kick off in a few days we will just have to wait and see where the museums inventory ends up at, but it seems likely that many of these items which were publicly viewable will now be scattered across the globe in private collections.
Top image: A roughly 180° panorama of the conditioned room of the Living Computer Museum, Seattle, Washington, USA. Taken in 2014. (Credit: Joe Mabel)
title: クリスティーズオークションで売却される最初のコンピュータ史アイテム
body: クリスティーズ・オークションが「Gen One: Innovations from the Paul G. Allen Collection」の一環としてコンピュータ関連の品々を出品すると発表。オークションにはApple 1やPDP-10、マイクロソフトの初期メモなどが含まれる。私的コレクションへの分散が予想される。
titles: クリスティーズオークションで売却される最初のコンピュータ史アイテム
Apple 1やPDP-10など、初期のコンピューターがオクションで
シアトルのリビングコンピュータ博物館に展示されていたアイテムがオークションへ
プライベートコレクションに散在するかもしれない、コンピューター歴史の遺産
アルバート・アインシュタインの手紙や宇宙服も含む、オークションの注目アイテム
